texts.en: Hasan is a 49-year-old Lebanese man who lives with his wife and two school-aged children. He has been working in fruit and vegetable sales in his town since 1995. His products are carried on a trolley and he works on a freelance basis. Hasan has also worked in a local bakery since 2005 with the aim of earning more income. Today, he is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase metal stands and tables to better display his merchandise. In the future, he hopes to open his own shop.

loans.use: to purchase metal stands and tables to better display his merchandise.

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey is 27 and has been in active farming for four years, producing milk and eggs for the local market. He is single and says farming is his source of livelihood. He has a good relationship with Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo, having requested two previous loans amounting to 31,200 KES and 61,200 KES respectively.
Aggrey has now requested a loan of 61,200 KES to purchase and insure another dairy cow. This will bring his number of dairy cows to four and will  boost his farming income tremendously. He is focusing on starting a grain-grinding business, too. Aggrey says that the loans have made him financially stable and turned farming into employment which makes him confident of having and taking care of a family. He says food and water shortages during dry seasons remain a major challenge.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy more poultry birds.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 35-year-old businesswoman who lives in Juba. She is married and has two children between the ages of five and two. One of her children goes to school. 

Jackline runs a clothing store business and has been in the business for three years. She has one employee. Jackline heard about Finance Sudan through fellow clients. Jackline is taking a loan of 1,000 SDG to purchase more clothing, bags, and many other items. Besides this business, Jackline has no other source of income. 

In five years time, Jackline would like to have an increment in her business size and be in a good shop.  

Her major challenges include a low income rate and home expenses.   

Jackline says that she is happy for Finance Sudan’s support in South Sudan, which has made them able to pay their children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing, bags, and other items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add stock of trousers, blouses, skirts, and sweaters.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is from Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Fe is married and has one child. 

To earn a living, Fe operates a business venture, raising pigs for sale. Fe has been in business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Fe is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. In 2011, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve both her business and her living situation. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the loan as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon is a 31-year-old married woman who has been living in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. Phon is skillful in making things from clay such as cookers, pots and oter containers. After she makes them, her husband transports them to sell in the local markets of the province. Together, they are able to generate around $5.00 per day to raise their two single children who are attending in a local state school. 

And now Phon decided to ask for some funds from Kiva to buy more stocks of merchandises (pot, cooker…etc.) for sale and to fix a trailer that is used to transport the products. She hopes that she’ll be able to create more income, which she will save for her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of merchandises (pot, cooker…etc.) for sale and to fix a trailer.

loans.name: 03.1.15 Quảng Hưng Thanh Hoa Group

texts.en:
Đằm operates a food stall selling beverages. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to maintain the refeshment bar (small bar with coffee, tea, soft drink, fast food…). Đằm has been involved in this business for 5 years.

Đằm is 49-years-old, is single and lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, a urban town in Thanh Hoa province

She is the leader of a 3-member group, the 15 Quảng Hưng solidarity group. 

In 2007, Đằm joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Đằm has successfully repaid 6 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

The main harship that Đằm faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Đằm hopes to build a new house and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase materials to maintain the refeshment bar.

loans.name: Fedelita

texts.en:
Fedelita is married woman and gifted with two children. At her age of 47, Fedelita’s children are between the ages of 20 to 26. 

Fedelita has run a hog raising business for three years. With the profits she earned from the business, she successfully sent her children to college and now already they have work. 

Fedelita still wants to maintain her business even though her children already finished their education. Fedelita wants to maintain the business to have savings. Fedelita knows that she is getting old. She has to prepare for her future emergencies with her husband.

Fedelita is requesting a loan of P20,000 to purchase feed for the maintenance of pigs.

loans.use: to purchase feed for the maintenance of pigs.

loans.name: Sainte Cathérine Plus Group

texts.en:
Mireille is the chairwoman of the Community Bank named “Ste Catherine Plus” which is composed of 12 micro entrepreneurs. These members are united for the same goal to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC. 

Mireille is 33-years-old. Her main activity is to sell eggs. She buys them in bulk and resells them to individual consumers at profit. She sells her products daily in downtown Kinshasa. She started her business in 2006. She is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having eleven times obtained and correctly repaid loans. Her next loan will allow her to buy eggs in larger quantities to increase her sales in order to make a better profit. Its business makes a profit of about US$50 per week. The aims of this loan are mainly for reinforcing the working capital and food for her family. Mireille is married and the mother of seven children whose ages vary between 1 and 16 years old. Five of them attend school. She dreams to someday become an egg provider in her environment.

loans.use: to buy eggs in larger quantities for resale at profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize cereal to sell.

loans.name: Darine

texts.en: Darine is a 29-year-old married woman with three children who are still attending school. She has been selling women’s and children’s clothes from her home for the past three years. With the unstable socio-economic situation in Lebanon, her husband was obliged to travel and work outside the country in order to better support the family. Today, Darine is requesting a loan of $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase more clothes to sell. In the future, she plans to open her own clothing store.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Majeedan's Group

texts.en:
Majeedan has no children and lives with her husband.  The couple operate a clothes selling business together, and both of them have vast experience in this field.  Majeedan has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah. She will use the money to buy a wide variety of clothes in bulk quantity, which will allow her to attract more clients and increase her sales and profits.  She is very confident that an investment will help her business to grow and that she and her husband will be in better financial shape as a result.

Note: In the picture, Majeedan is third from the left, with a book in her hand.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of clothes in bulk quantity for her clothes selling business

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. She is married with 3 children between 7 and 15 years old, all of whom attend school.  She has practiced farming consistently for 5 years. Her farm currently produces milk, eggs and vegetables, which she sells at the local market. She has requested a loan of 51,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says this will help provide milk for family consumption as well as for retail sale to customers, and will earn her more income for other basic needs. She wants to own four dairy cows in five years’ time.  She laments the high cost of feeds in dry seasons, coupled with animal diseases.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Harlenita

texts.en:
Harlenita is a married woman with two children. Harlenita is 43 years old and resides in Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Harlenita owns and operates a farm, planting and harvesting rice for sale to earn a living. She's been in this business for 15 years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of work. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer, such as manure. 

Harlenita has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Harlenita wants her children to complete their education and to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, such as manure.

loans.name: Na

texts.en:
Na, 42, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She grows rice and raises animals. Her husband is a construction foreman. Her three children are also employed at a garment factory in the city for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Na is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work in the city. By doing so, she is able to cut down the expense on the public transportation. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more chicks to rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a resident and farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. He is married with 3 children aged between 15 and 2 years. He has been farming for 8 years and produces milk, tomatoes, and eggs for the local market with the help of one farmhand on his farm.

Charles has requested a loan of 46,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the dairy cow will improve his milk production and income and in turn make the needs of his family a possibility. He also wants to venture into cereal processing in the local market for more income, as well as increase his stock of dairy cows to five.

He sees the frequent occurrences of diseases as the main undoing in farming.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Bokoli Plus Group

texts.en:
Emile is the leader of the Community Bank named “Bokoli Plus,” which is composed of 15 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Emile has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2005. He operates a general store in the mid-east of Kinshasa. He has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize his dream of one day opening a pig farm. He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business that earns him $20 per week. He works to the best of his abilities and uses his contacts so that he might achieve his goals. Emile is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having obtained and correctly repaid loans five times. He will diversify his business by buying a cassava mill in order to generate additional profits. Emile is 53 years old, married, and the father of six children, whose ages vary between 3 and 31 years old. Four of his children attend school.

loans.use: to diversify his business by buying a cassava mill in order to generate additional profits.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: 3.1.10 Quảng Hưng Thanh Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Tráng runs a horse cart transport service. She is requesting a loan to purchase a carriage for the transport service. She has been involved in this business for five years. Tráng is 49 years old and she is married with three children. She lives with one dependent in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province. The main hardship that Tráng faces in her business is lack of capital. With her business profit, Tráng hopes for her children to find good jobs, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her business to do well.

In 2008, Tráng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Tráng has successfully repaid six loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She is the leader of this three member group, the 3.1.10 Quảng Hưng solidarity group.

loans.use: to purchase a carriage for a transport service.

loans.name: Abdulmumin

texts.ru: Абдулмумин проживает в районе Хамадони. Ему 66 лет. Он женат. У него шестеро детей. Кроме того у него внуки и внучки. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он занимается выращиванием овощей, пшеницы и бахчевых культур. Этим видом деятельности занимается четыре года. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Abdulmumin lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 66 years old, married and has six children. He is also a proud grandfather of two grandchildren. His wife stays at home while Abdulmumin is a farmer and grows vegetables, wheat and melons. He has been farming for the last four years and is requesting this loan to purchase fertilizer for his crops.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en:
Thanh is 30 years old. She is married and has two children. They are still small. She and her husband have a computer shop. They buy and sell computers (old and new). They have had this business for five years. They have a monthly income of about 7,000,000 Vietnam dong (VND). 

Since 2007, Mrs Thanh has participated in SEDA. The last time she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 9,632,000 VND to buy more computers and other things for her shop.

loans.use: to buy more computers and other things for her shop.

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Sary, 48, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She grows rice and raises pigs at home. Her rice production is enough for her family, and she is able to sell her rice to middlemen as well. Her husband is a commune clerk. Her two children are also employed at a garment factory in the city for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Sary is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her daughter to commute to study at a university. By doing so, she is able to cut down the expense on the public transportation for her family members. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her daughter to commute to study.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is married with seven children, ages 6 to 25. He has been a maize farmer for 25 years. He would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow his crop. He will use this Kiva loan to pay for labor costs and fertilizer for maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. He wishes to invest the profits from his farming in his business, so that he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity in the future.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers, seeds, and pesticides to grow his crop.

loans.name: 060301-Đại Giang-Hoằng Châu Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hòa farms shrimp and crabs. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby shrimp and crabs to raise to sell in the future.

Hòa is 47 years old and she is married with three children.
She is the leader of a four member group, the 060301-Đại Giang-Hoằng Châu solidarity group. 
She lives and works in Hoang Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2005, Hòa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hòa has successfully repaid five loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hòa has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.
One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Hòa hopes to remodel her house, to maintain a successful business, and to provide for her kids.

loans.use: to purchase baby shrimp and crab to raise to sell

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
At the age of 41, Reynaldo is still single. Being determined to help his parent even in just a simple way, Reynaldo runs a hog raising business. He started this business six years ago. He is happy that he maintains his business even though he faces financial problems in maintaining his pig feed.
Reynaldo doesn’t want to lose hope that he can continue his business. He will treat all obstacles in growing his business as individual challenges. He believes that he can continue his business and he will strive for the growth of his business. 
Reynaldo wants a loan of P20,000 to purchase hog feed. He wants the loan to have a positive impact on his business.

loans.use: to purchase hog feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy poultry

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is 39 years old, married and blessed with five children.  To earn a living, he does shoe repairs.  He has been in the business for over ten years. He has experienced a lot of growth in his business since he joined Faulu Kenya.

He hopes to grow his business in five years.  He believes that through his hard work, he will become a successful business-man. He needs 60,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy shoe soles and leather.

loans.use: to buy shoe soles and leather.

loans.name: Venantie

texts.en:
Venantie has 2 children. She has been a maize farmer for 14 years. She would like a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and pesticides.

She will use the Kiva loan to support labor and fertilizer costs during maize production: they need fertilizers to increase production.
 
With the profits from her farming she wants to invest in her business so that, in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa is 55 years old. She lives in Pho Cho town, Yen Phong, bac Ninh. She has a general store. She sells cobbler. She has had this job for 5 years. She has a monthly income of about 5.000.000 Vietnamdong(VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2007. The last time she borrowed 6.048.000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle she would like to borrow 9.632.000 VND to buy items such as foodstuffs, drinks and dairy products for her store.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs, drinks and dairy products for her store.

loans.name: 0404013-Hải Sơn-Hoằng Trường Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Sen has a retail business selling seafood. She is requesting a loan to maintain her fishing boat to catch fish to sell.

Sen is 28 years old and she is married with 2 children.
She is the leader of a 4-member group, the 0404013-Hải Sơn-Hoằng Trường solidarity group. 
She lives and works in Hoang Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with 2 dependents.

In 2011, Sen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Sen has successfully repaid 1 loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.
Sen has been involved in her business for 3 years.
One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is lack of capital.

With her business profits, Sen hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to be healthy and happy, and to maintain a successful business.

loans.use: to maintain her fishing boat to catch fish to sell.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is a married woman with three children. She is 35 years old and resides at Capucao, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.
 
Editha earns a living by operating a business raising crops, planting and harvesting root crops such as cassava to sell. She has been in this business for ten years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase land to raise additional crops. Editha has been a member of GDMPC for almost four years.
 
In the future, Editha wants to make improvements to her house and wants her children to finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase land to raise additional crops.

loans.name: Inna

texts.ru: Инна замужем и имеет двоих детей. Она имеет свой бизнес и продает женскую одежду. Она ездит по маленьким близлежащим городам и продает там свой товар. Инна занимается этим бизнесом уже 13 лет. Она целеустремлённая, предприимчивыая, живая и трудолюбивая. Инне нравится то, что она делает и она намерена развивать этот бизнес дальше. Инна просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 10,000 гривен на закупку женских свитеров, кофт, курточек к холодному времени года.
texts.en: Inna is married and has two children. She works in retail and sells women's clothing. Inna travels to the small towns in the region and sells her wares this way. She has been in this business for the last 13 years. Inna is a goal oriented an enterprising, energetic and hardworking. She like what she does and wants to expand her business further. Inna is requesting a loan of 10,000 grivn to purchase a large batch of women's sweaters, cardigans and jackets for the winter season.

loans.use: to purchase women's sweaters, cardigans and jackets

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok, 42, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. Sok and her husband are farmers. Her rice production is enough for her family, and she is able to also sell her rice to fulfill the market demand. Three of her children are employed at a garment factory in the city for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Sok is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached for her son to provide transportation services. By doing so, she is able to generate more income for her family. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. Sok appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her son to provide transportation services.

loans.name: Mary  Ngina

texts.en: Mary is applying for a second loan to add more blouses and skirts to her inventory. She repaid her previous loan well and in good time and her business is doing well. In the future, Mary hopes to expand her business and stock a wider variety of clothes.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes worth Kshs.25,000 and buy fertilizer and maize seeds for farming

loans.name: Gavkhar

texts.ru: Гавхар 50 лет, замужем и имеет троих детей. Двое старших сыновей работают, один – официантом, другой – развозчиком продуктов питания, младшая дочь учится в школе. В поисках источника финансирования своей семьи, энергичная Гавхар начала свой бизнес в разведении скота и перепродаже сельхоз продукции. Гавхар использовала стартовую сумму в 15,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота, и сумела развить свое хозяйство, имеющее на сегодняшний день четыре бычка.  Также, Гавхар готовит у себя на дому лапшу для лагмана (национальное блюдо из зажаренного мяса и лапши), которая по рецепту должна быть сделана  и растянута вручную и сдает ее на реализацию в продуктовые магазины. Благодаря ежемесячной прибыли в сумме около 20,000 сом (KGS) Гавхар покрывает ежедневные расходы своей семьи и откладывает деньги на обучение для младшей дочери. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гавхар обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме  100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота для откорма и перепродажи. В ближайшее время, при помощи доходов от кредита, семья Гавхар планирует приобрести машину, чтобы предоставлять услуги такси.
texts.en: Gavkhar is 50 years old, married and has three children. Her two older sons work, one as a waiter and the other one as a grocery truck driver, while the youngest daughter is still in school. To be able to support her family, Gavkhar is raising cattle and sells produce at the market. She has started her business with 15,000 som (KGS) which she used to purchase cattle and has now expanded her herd to four calves. Additionally, Gavkhar makes pasta for the lagman (a traditional Kyrgyz dish of roasted meat and pasta) which she sells to the local grocery stores. According to the recipe, pasta for lagman has to be made and stretched out completely by hand. Gavkhar's business yields 20,000 som (KGS) monthly in profits and this allows her to cover all daily expenses as well as save money for her daughter's education. In order to grow her business Gavkhar has turned to "Bai-Tushum and Partners" for a credit of 100,000 som (KGS) with which she plans to buy additional cattle for fattening and resale. Her family is planning to use the profits from the loan to purchase a car and open a taxi service in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase food spices, onions, and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: 05.01.41 Điện Biên Thanh Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hòa operates a food stall selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetables to sell. She is 54 years old and married with three children. Hòa is the leader of a 5-member group, the 05.01.41 Điện Biên solidarity group. She lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province. All of her children got jobs, 2 sons is carpenter and 1 daughter has a vegetable stall in market.

In 2010, Hòa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. She has successfully repaid 2 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hòa has been involved in here business for 6 years, her main hardship being the lack of capital. With her business profit, Hòa hopes her childrenwill find good jobs, to be able to remodel her house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase vegetable to sell.

loans.name: Cheronoh

texts.en:
Cheronoh, a farmer in Litein South Rift, Kenya is 29 and married with 3 children, with the first born already in school. She has 6 years experience in active farming and currently produces milk and tea which she sell locally. Her family relies on completely on farming for their upkeep.

Cheronoh has made a loan request through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo of 40,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. She says the cow will provide milk for the family and more income for other basic needs. She notes that farmers' access to finances is her major challenge and advocates for loan services to be broadened.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Munhochir

texts.en: Munhochir is 33 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed and their daughter is in kindergarden. As his brother suggested, he started to work as an carrier in 2007. After two years he began a driving course and started his own business of transportation. Personally, he is a clever and conversable man. He earnestly says "Road between Ulaanbaatar and Uvurhangai is source of our family's income." His business will grow faster if he repairs his car, therefore he is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to do so.

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Sareoun

texts.en:
Sareoun, 47, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

She sells Cambodian noodles. Her husband is a farmer. Also, two of her children are employed at a garment factory in the city for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Sareoun is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to provide transportation services. By doing so, she will be able to generate more income for the family. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. Sareoun appears in the photograph with her mother.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike  for her brother to provide transportation services.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 32 years old, married and a father of four children who are in school.  He has been in business for four years and has employed two people. 

He runs a grocery business to earn extra income.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has managed to grow his business because he has been able to access financial resources easily.

Martin has requested for 80,000 Kenya Shillings to buy milk.

loans.use: to buy milk for his business.

loans.name: Rasheed

texts.en: Rasheed is a 27 year-old man and a worker with a decent salary. Rasheed wants to help his brother, who is a university student, pay his fees, but the amount of money he has isn't enough, so he needs to take a loan from FATEN. When Rasheed gets the loan, he will be able to help his brother pay the university fees and complete his study to get the first university degree. This will change Rasheed's brother life positively and provide the opportunity to get better work in the future.

loans.use: To pay his brother's university fees.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 36 years old an enterprising business lady. She is married to James, who is a farmer. She has been running a retail shop for the past three years. She earns a monthly income of KES 10,000, which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for her third loan term from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. Esther will use the loan to buy a stock of sugar, maize meal, and rice for sale. 

With the anticipated profit from the business she will educate her children.  Her hope s and dreams are to open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy a stock of sugar, maize meal and rice for sale.

loans.name: 3.1.62 Quảng Hưng Thanh Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Len operates a food stall selling vegetables. She is requesting a loan to purchase vegetables for resale.

Len is 57 years old and is married with 2 children.
She is the leader of a 6-member group, the 3.1.62 Quảng Hưng solidarity group. 
Len lives with 2 dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Len joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Len has successfully repaid 2 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.
Len has been involved in this business for 2 years.
The main hardship she faces in her business is lack of capital.

With her business profits, Len hopes for her children to find a good job, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to remodel her house.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Nyamsuren

texts.en: Nyamsuren is 24 years old and lives with his wife in a ger (Mongolian tent) in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. His wife runs a clothes selling business. He started his taxi service business in 2008 with his own taxi. His taxi service income is pretty constant therefore he wants to expand his wife's shop. He is a sharp and hardworking man who says, "We have a baby coming, so I have to do everything I can to increase my income. I don't want my baby to live like me, uneducated, broke". He is requesting 1,100,000 MNT to buy clothes from Erlian for his wife's business.

loans.use: To buy clothes from Erlian

loans.name: Chepkemoi

texts.en:
Chepkemoi is the mother of two children aged 8 and 4. She has been in farming for 5 years producing and selling tea and milk at the local market. She also retails tea which she sources from her farm and other farmers.

Chepkemoi has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry to venture into poultry farming. She adds that the poultry business has become lucrative and offers quicker returns which she wants to exploit. She says the income will be used to meet family needs.

She also says that lack of finances is the major challenge for farmers.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is from the village of Alindahaw, Tukuran, Zambaonga Del Sur. She is 36 years old. Judith is married and has one school-aged child.

To make a living, Judith owns and operates a tricycle transport service. A tricycle is a motorcycle with a passenger cab. Judith has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Judith is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a vehicle used in the business.

In 2008, Judith joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation.
She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to repair a vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase beans, sorghum, and other items for resale.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is a farmer. She is single and the mother of one child aged 2. She has been in farming for 6 years in her home area of Litein South Rift Kenya. Her farm produces milk and tea for the local market. She says farming is her only source of income for the upkeep of herself and her child.

Joice has requested a loan of 20,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. She says this will boost her farming income and improve her standard of living. She is confident of this result from her experience in dairy farming for 6 years.

She says dairy farmers face great challenges during the dry season due to the high cost of feed.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Rosenia

texts.en: Rosenia, 55 years old, is married and has 4 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Rosenia is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Rosenia has been raising pigs for 6 years and also earns additional income from two other businesses: a boarding house and a delivery truck which she rents. Rosenia works tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Tsogtbayar

texts.en: Tsogtbayar is 22 years old and lives with his brother in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Hovd province, Mongolia. His brother is a student. Tsogtbayar started his cell phone repair and sales business in 2009 by renting a counter in the market when he finished his cell phone repair training. He also sells secondhand cell phones. Now that cell phones are becoming more advanced, Tsogtbayar needs to buy some equipment in order to repair these phones. He has already taken training in repairing Smartphones; he only requires the appropriate equipment. Due to his cash shortage, Tsogtbayar is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to buy new cell phones from Ulaanbaatar.

loans.use: To buy new cell phones from Ulaanbaatar

loans.name: Calexto

texts.en:
Calexto only finished his elementary level of education and did not have the chance to enter high school. Now, he is 37 years old and married, with four children. Calexto has managed his business raising hogs for 10 years.

Calexto is experiencing financial difficulties because he has four children who need to finance their daily allowances in school. He does not have enough capital to maintain his hogs. Calexto would like a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy feed for his hogs in order to continue his business. It would be a great help for him to maintain his business and bestow his children's needs in school.

loans.use: to buy pig feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items like green pepper, lemon, onions, and tomatoes

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 46 years old and married, with 4 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Rebecca is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Rebecca has been raising pigs for 3 years and also earns additional income from her sari-sari store, motorcycle transport and vulcanizing (tire) shop businesses. She works tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business so she can secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
As a married parent of 2 children, Gina works hard to support her family. She has a food production business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from selling fish and making furniture. Gina is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients and utensils for her food production business.

Gina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF.  She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and utensils

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 49 years old and has three children.  To earn a living she does tailoring.  She has 19 years of experience in the business and has employed one person.   She also works as a housekeeper when her business is in low season.  Through Faulu Kenya, she has learnt better ways of running her business because she has been trained in business management skills.

Elizabeth hopes to open a wholesale business in the future.  She needs 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to renovate her business premise by adding more shelves and to buy fabric.

loans.use: to renovate her business premise by adding shelves and to buy fabric.

loans.name: Hillary

texts.en:
Hillary is 18 years old and single. He runs an M-pesa (mobile phone based money transfer) shop. He has been in business for two years.  

Right now his monthly income from the business is KES 26,000. He is borrowing KES 50,000 to increase the float (stored-value credits) in his business. Hillary plans to repay the loan with the anticipated profit from the business and to open another M-pesa location. 

This is Hillary's first loan. He hopes and dreams to run a big business and to be a role model in the area.

loans.use: to add float (stored-value credits) to the business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old. Erlinda is married and has four children. 

To make a living, Erlinda operates a fishing business, selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Erlinda has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Erlinda is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. In 2008, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Tumenbayar

texts.en:
Borrower Tumenbayar is a 43-year-old widow who has two daughters and lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She has higher education in both accounting and nutrition technology. Her younger daughter attends the Royal academy in Mongolia, while her elder daughter helps her to operate the business.   

Regardless of her profession, she had six years of experience in her own grocery and home furnishing store, until she went to South Korea for a higher paying job for five years. After she came back from S. Korea in 2010, she continued her small grocery store business. 

Tumenbayar is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) loan to buy more merchandise for the grocery store. Her goal is to improve her business in order to increase her working capital and expand her business as well.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise for the grocery store

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia settled into marriage when she was 23 years old. She did not finish her college education and did not seek employment. She involved herself in rice farming to generate an income. She inherited this hectare plot of land from her parents. She has been cultivating it for almost two years and earns 10,000 PHP each harvest season during the month of April and November. 

Celia is now 28 years old, has two children and is married to a truck driver. She is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to pay for land cultivation and to buy pesticides and herbicides used in farming. She needs to improve her crop production, and hiring laborers for land cultivation is an additional expense for her. 

In the future, Celia would like to achieve a plentiful harvest every season to save for the education of her children.

loans.use: to pay for land cultivation and buy pesticides and herbicides used in farming.

loans.name: Waddah

texts.en: Waddah is a 23-year-old young man.  He has an Internet cafe, which is his only source of income.  Waddah wants to expand his cafe to increase his income by purchasing more computers but the amount of money he has isn't enough to pay for them, so he needs to borrow a loan of $1,000 from FATEN. When Waddah gets the loan he will be able to purchase more computers and increase the size of his cafe.  This will increase the number of customers to his cafe and increase his income.  Waddah is photographed in the picture.

loans.use: to purchase more computers for his internet cafe.

loans.name: Samba

texts.fr:
Monsieur Samba est une homme marié de 32 et père de 3 enfants qui réside avec sa femme et ses enfants à Bougouni.
Ayant vite abandonné l’école, il commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus telles l’achat et la vente de chaussures, de céréales pendant des années et cela sans réussite. Alors, il décide d’apprendre auprès de son oncle, les activités d’achat vente de friperies. Il mène son  activité à la gare routière de Bougouni et dans les marchés hebdomadaires.
Avec une expérience de plus de 10 années, il maîtrise son activité.
Afin d'agrandir son entreprise, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt  3 balles de friperie à Bamako auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Avec ce prêt il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70.000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et le reste investi dans l’activité.
Il ambitionne d’être grossiste à Bougouni.
texts.en:
Samba is 32, married and the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife and children in Bougouni. He left school at a young age and quickly started in business, buying and selling shoes, and selling cereals for a few years. Unfortunately, these enterprises failed and he decided to learn from his uncle, who bought and sold second hand clothing. Samba now sells second hand clothes at the Bougouni bus station and the weekly markets, and is a skillful salesman with 10 years experience in the business.

Samba decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso so that he could invest in his business and expand his activities. This is his first loan request with the institution and he will use the money to buy 3 bales of second hand clothing from the wholesalers in Bamako. He will resell the clothes to his large and varied customer base, for cash or credit. He predicts an average monthly profit of 70 000 francs, which he will use to repay the loan and support his family. He plans to reinvest any extra money back in his business. His ultimate goal is to become a wholesaler in Bougouni.

loans.use: to buy second hand clothing for resale.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a farmer and father of nine children, six of whom are of school going age. He is aged 50 and has 20 years of experience in mixed farming in the Litein area of South Rift Kenya. His farm currently produces milk,maize and beans which he sells locally.

Francis has requested for a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to help him buy and insure a dairy cow. He says this will improve his farming income which he will use to meet his family basic needs especially the education of the children.

He adds that sources of farming capital are limited, but the intervention by Juhudi Kilimo through the farming loans is a great help to farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Shareefan's Group

texts.en:
Shareefan is 41 years old, married and has two sons. Both of them stay at home and don’t do anything. Her eldest son is 20 years old and looking for a job.

Shareefan is very supportive and helps her husband financially by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from the wholesale market and sells them to her community clients for a profit. She also operates a grocery business from her home. She has converted her guest room into a grocery store through which she sells daily use items such as salt, sugar, spices etc. Her husband is a daily wage laborer and works for a low income. 

Shareefan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her grocery store business. With the loan investment, she will buy grocery items such as spices, cooking oils etc in bulk quantity. She will be able to offer a greater variety of products and increase her sales and profits.
She has been operating her business for the past few years and is confident about her business success as a result of loan investment.

loans.use: to buy spices, cooking oils etc for her grocery store business

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita is 44 years old and has four children, one of whom is in school. Benita is married.

Benita is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Benita has been raising pigs for three years now and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Benita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Warakas 8 Gaspul Group

texts.en:
Nani is a mother of three children. She has been selling rice and other dishes for 16 years from a cart on the street corner near her home. She also sells newspapers.  Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver.  She enjoys selling food from her cart because it can supplement her husband's constantly varying income.  One of her children is of school age and is currently attending the 5th grade. The business is going well but now she needs to make repairs to her cart.  She will use this loan to do so.

She hopes that all of her children can attend the university and the family will have enough money to pay for it.  She herself only attended school until 9th grade so her children's education is important to her.  

The other group members will use their loans for their businesses which include selling peanuts and "krupuk" (Indonesian chips), selling "nasi uduk" (an Indonesian coconut rice dish), selling rice, running a grocery store, and fixing electronics.

loans.use: to pay for repairing her food cart.

loans.name: Tuvshinbaatar

texts.en: Tuvshinbaatar is 51 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed. Two sons are college students and they sometimes help with their father's business. He started his joinery business in 2001. Now he makes a lot of wood products and furniture to order. Personally, he is laconic and a strenuous worker who says, "I need to broaden my business and get more income to educate my children well." He needs a 3,800,000 Mongolian tugrik (MNT) loan for buying wood planks and a lathe for his business.

loans.use: To buy wood planks and a lathe

loans.name: Vardan

texts.ru:
Вардану 29 лет, он проживает в Ванадзоре. Вардан не женат и живет с родителями. 
У Вардана высшее инженерное образование, но он никогда не работал по своей специальности. Уже 2 года Вардан занимается распространением кофе, сухих завтраков и сладостей. Он покупает товары в Ереване и сдает их в магазины города Ванадзора и деревень Лорийского марза. У Вардана есть небольшой грузовой автомобиль, с помощью которого он перевозит товары из Еревана в место сдачи товара в Ванадзоре и деревнях. Благодаря своему небольшому бизнесу он содержит семью. 
Вардану требуется кредит на сумму 500.000 драм для приобретения зимних покрышек для своего грузового автомобиля и для его небольшого ремонта.
texts.en:
Vardan is 29 years old and lives in Vanadzor. He is single and lives with his parents. Vardan has a college degree in Engineering but he has never been able to work in his profession. Instead, for the last two years Vardan has been running a grocery delivery service. He purchases coffee, cereal and sweets in Yerevan and resells them to stores in Vanadzor and the villages of the Lori region. Vardan owns a small delivery truck which he uses to transport the goods from Yerevan. This small business allows him to support his parents. 

Vardan would like to take out a loan of 500,000 dram to purchase winter tires for his truck and to make small repairs to the vehicle.

loans.use: To buy winter tire casings for his truck and also to dye his truck

loans.name: Turmunkh

texts.en: Turmunkh is a 27-year-old single guy who lives in a small house in an outer ger (Mongolian housing tents) district without basic infrastructure. He lives with his 50-year-old father and mother. He is a well-educated young man, and he operates his own small business. The family lives in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. In 2008, he started his wood-sawing business at Gandan, the very religious part of the city. He has one big Russian saw and with this tool, he made money. Also, he hired two guys to support him. In the winter season, his business becomes more popular and he needs more oil for his saw. He is requesting a 2,700,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) loan to purchase oil for his saw and prepay his two employees. Furthermore, his long-term aim is to improve his business and live happily with his mom and dad.

loans.use: to purchase oil for his saw.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 36-year-old businessman. He is married to Jane, who is a business lady. They are blessed with two children, aged 9 and 7 years respectively. He has been running a hardware shop for the past 10 years with the monthly income of 10,000 Kenyan shillings, which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his third loan term with KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. Stephen will use the loan to buy vehicle spare parts to add to his stock. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. His hopes and dreams are to open a retail shop and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts to add to his stock.

loans.name: Munkhjargal

texts.en:
Munkhjargal is a 27-year-old young entrepreneur who lives with her mother in the outer "ger" district, a district without basic infrastructure in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her mother is retired, so she stays at home while Munkhjargal supports her family by operating a business selling accessories and cosmetic products. She has been doing this for the last four years. 

Now she has 4.5 million MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) in working capital. Besides operating her small business, she studied at local medical institute. She said about her business: “To sell cosmetic products and accessories is very important in winter, spring and autumn, because there will be a lot of traditional and international holidays.”  

So she is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for the upcoming season. Her goal is to improve her business as well as to make a better living condition for her mother.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetic products for upcoming season.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 52 years old, married and has one child. To make a living, Luzviminda runs a general store selling a variety of food and home use products such as candies, cigarettes, shampoo, soaps and many other items in her community. Luzviminda has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,600 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

Luzviminda is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. In 2010, Luzviminda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the loan as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a farmer in Kitale, Westen Kenya. He is married with 5 children who are all in school. He has been in mixed farming for 5 years producing maize, milk, and eggs which he takes to the local market for sale.

John has made a third loan request of 61,200 KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. His previous loans of 30,000 KES and 61,200 KES were promptly paid. He says the loan will help boost his milk production, meeting the demand of family consumption and selling the rest to meet other family needs.

John laments the high cost of dairy feeds and rampant diseases which consume a lot of resources.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Azhar

texts.en: Azhar is a 40-year-old woman. She is is married with three sons and two daughters. Her husband is a worker who earns a decent salary. Azhar has a grocery store. She is requesting a loan from FATEN to purchase more groceries to resell. When Azhar gets the loan, she will improve her store and offer a better selection of groceries. With her increased income, she will be able to provide better living conditions for her family. Azhar is the woman shown in the photograph.

loans.use: to purchase groceries to resell.

loans.name: Kamunevu Farmers Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kamunevu Farmers Group in Western Kenya! With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Raphael and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Raphael is the facilitator of the Kamunevu Farmers Group. In the photograph above, Raphael is pictured with his group members and the field officer standing on the far left. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Kamunevu Farmers Group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Raphael takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Raphael had a very good maize yield harvesting 13 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Raphael was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Raphael will ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

loans.use: to source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 41 years old. Concepcion is married and has seven children.

To earn a living, Concepcion is operating a fishing business, selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Concepcion has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Concepcion is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. In 2011, Concepcion joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Maunda Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Maunda SHG Group in Western Kenya! Beatrice is the facilitator of the Maunda SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Beatrice takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Beatrice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 14 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest five bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Beatrice will educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Maunda SHG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows seven women.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Darthy's Group

texts.en:
Darthy is 57 years old. She is still very active and performs her routine tasks very well. She also sews clothes for her neighboring clients and earns reasonably good profits every month.

She has given birth to two sons and three daughters. Her eldest son is a plumber while the youngest one is studying in the ninth grade. Two of her three daughters also work to contribute financially to the family.

Darthy has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her clothes sewing business. With the loan, she will purchase clothes for sewing and selling to her clients for profit.

She is an experienced businesswoman and confident that her business will grow well after a loan investment.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her clothes sewing business.

loans.name: Safi Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Safi Group in Western Kenya! Pamela is the facilitator of the Safi group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Pamela takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, Pamela had an excellent maize yield harvesting 41 1/2 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Pamela was only able to harvest 1 1/2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Pamela and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Pamela will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Safi Group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows three members: two women and one man. The field officer appears at the far left of the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a hardworking business-woman, aged 41.  She is married and blessed with three children all of whom attend school.  She has been running a boutique and cosmetic shop for the last five years to support her family.  She has employed one person to assist her to manage the business.

Irene has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers.  She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings to add to the stock of clothes for resale.  In the next five years she wants to expand her business.  Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has become more financially stable.

loans.use: to add the stock of clothes in her shop.

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr:
Améyo est une femme âgé(e) de 30 ans. Elle est mariée å un  vulcanisateur.  Elle a 02 enfants, dont 01 à l’école. Le premier a 05 ans et le dernier a 02 ans.  
Améyo travaille comme revendeuse de gâteau ( aliment fait à base de farine de blé) depuis 2008. Elle sert ses clients à la maison.
Améyo a requis son second  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter de la farine de blé, de l’huile.
Dans les prochaines années, Améyo voudrait diversifier l’activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit assurer les besoins vitaux de la famille.
texts.en:
Améyo is a thirty-year-old woman. She is married to a tire repairman.  She has two children, one of whom attends school. The oldest is 5 years old, the youngest is two.   

Améyo has been selling cakes (a food made from wheat flour) since 2008. She delivers to her customers at home.

Améyo has requested a second loan from WAGES to buy wheat flour and oil.

In the coming years, Améyo would like to diversify her business. She says that with the profits she will provide for the vital needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour and oil.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a hardworking business man and  blessed with four children, three of whom attend school.  He has been farming for the last ten years to support his family. He is also employed as a teacher.  

He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy seeds. In the next five years, he plans to open a school.

loans.use: to buy seeds for his farm.

loans.name: Lucy Mbaika

texts.en:
Lucy Mbaika Musymi used her first loan well. She bought clothes which she sold at a good profit. She paid her previous loan well and in good time. 


She has currently applied for a new loan which she intends to use to add more stock of clothes for the festive season and thus maximize on the sales. 

In the future, Lucy hopes to expand her business and generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of clothes

loans.name: Upendo A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Upendo A Group in Western Kenya!  Evalyne is the facilitator of the Upendo A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Evalyne takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and in order to have a good harvest. In the recent 2011 season, Evalyne had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Evalyne was only able to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Evalyne and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Evalyne will ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Upendo A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Evalyne is pictured with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Batokari

texts.fr:
Batokari est une femme  âgé(e) de 47 ans. Elle est mariée à un jardinier. Elle a 05 enfants tous scolarisés. L’ainé a 24ans et le dernier a14ans.
Batokari travaille comme revendeuse de bois de chauffe, du maïs et des beignets depuis 2004. Elle vend à la maison à toutes personnes.
Batokari a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des bois de chauffe, du maïs.
Dans les prochaines années, Batokari voudrait diversifier la vente de céréales pour créer une plus large clientèle. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit assurer les besoins en alimentation de la famille.
texts.en:
Batokari is 47 years old. She is married to a gardener. She has five children all attending (or having attended) school. The eldest is 24 years old and the youngest is 14.

Batokari has been retailing firewood, corn and doughnuts since 2004. She sells from her home to all-comers.

Batokari requested her first loan from WAGES to buy firewood and corn.

In coming years, Batokari would like to diversify her sale of grains to widen her customer base. She stated that with the profits, she intends to meet her family's food requirements.

loans.use: Buy firewood and corn

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a resident and a farmer in Litein, South Rift, Kenya. He is married with 5 children, all of school-going age. His farm currently produces tea, which he sells to Kenya Tea Development Authority, as well as milk and maize, which go to the local market. 

Elijah has requested a loan of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a chuff cutter at 50,000 KES and to construct a dairy unit at 30,000 KES. He says he expects improvement in his milk production due to better feeding and protection with the existence of the dairy unit. He adds the income will ensure a better livelihood for his entire family.

He says that the high cost of dairy feed takes up much of the farming costs, especially during dry seasons.

loans.use: To purchase a chuff cutter and construct a dairy unit

loans.name: Kimakina Group

texts.en:
Alfred is the facilitator of the Kimakina group. Alfred and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Alfred takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Alfred had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alfred was only able to harvest four bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alfred and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Alfred will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Kimakina group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Alfred is pictured with his group members and the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Victor

texts.ru:
Виктор женат, у него есть взрослый сын. Все втроем они живут в квартире в г. Бердянск. Виктор работает преподавателем в институте. Также он получает дополнительный доход, ремонтируя и обслуживая компьютеры.

Виктор просит предоставить ему кредит на ремонт квартиры. Он сможет поклеить обои, заменить канализацию и водопровод, поставить новые окна. Благодаря кредиту Виктор не только улучшит жилищные условия для своей семьи, но и расходовать меньше энергии и тепла за счет энергосберегающих окон.
texts.en:
Viktor is married and has a son. All three of them live in an apartment in the city of Berdyansk. Viktor is a professor at the local college and he supplements his salary by fixing and servicing computers.

Victor is asking for this loan to repair his apartment. He will be able to hang new wall paper, replace water and sewer pipes and install new windows. Due to this loan Victor will not only able to improve his family's living conditions but will use less energy and heat due to the new energy efficient windows.

loans.use: to hang wallpaper and repair plumbing and windows

loans.name: Kamo

texts.ru:
Камо  родился в 1962 г. в  селе Тандзавер (Tandzaver), Сюникского марза. После окончания средней школы он поступил в Капанский строительный техникум. В данный момент Камо работает в Капанском лесном хозяйстве.
Камо женат и  имеет двух детей: сына и дочь. Сыну 21 год, он учится в Горисском колледже на третьем курсе юридического факультета; дочери  24 года, она окончила Капанское медицинское училище, вышла замуж и сейчас проживает в России. Жена Камо работает библиотекаршей.
Сельским хозяйством Камо занимается уже почти 25 лет. Он владеет земельным участком, на котором выращивает овощи и фрукты. Также он разводит крупный рогатый скот и кур. Вместе с женой он реализует овощи из своего огорода на рынках Сюникского марза; а мясо, молоко, фрукты и нереализованные овощи у него покупают постоянные  клиенты: скупщики, прямо из дома. Благодаря занятию сельским хозяйством, Камо имеет возможность обеспечивать свою семью всем необходимым и платить за обучение сына. 
Камо  нужен кредит в 1.000.000 драм, для покупки восьми бычков и сена на зиму. 
Данный кредит является вторым по счету, получаемым Камо от организации Нор Оризон, и он выплатил данный кредит без просрочек.
texts.en:
Kamo was born in 1962 in the village of Tandzaver in the Sunikskiy region. After graduating from secondary school he enrolled in the Kapan college of civil engineering. At this time Kamo works in the Kapan forestry.

Kamo is married and has two children - a son and a daughter. His son is 21 years old and is studying his third year in the Gorisskiy college in the faculty of Law. His daughter is 24 years old, she graduated from the Kapan medical university, got married and now lives in Russia. Kamo's wife works as a librarian. 

Kamo has been doing farming for almost 25 years. He owns a plot of land where he grows mainly fruits and vegetables. He also breeds large horned cattle and chickens. Together with his wife he sells the vegetables on the markets of the Sunikskiy region, and the meat, milk and remaining unsold vegetables are bought by his regular customers straight from his home. Thanks to his farming business Kamo has the ability to provide for his family with all necessities and pay for his son's education.

Kamo needs a loan in the amount of 1,000,000 dram to buy eight calves and fodder for the winter. This is the second loan for Kamo which has been provided by the field partner Nor Orizon and he has paid it off without delinquencies.

loans.use: to buy eight calves and fodder for his farm animals.

loans.name: Juu Kali Shg Group

texts.en:
John is the facilitator of the Juu Kali SHG group.  John and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

John takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, John had an excellent maize yield harvesting six bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, John was only able to harvest three bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to John and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, John will invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Juu Kali SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, John is pictured with his group members and the field officer appears on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Khako Shg Group

texts.en:
James is the facilitator of the Khako SHG group. James and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

James takes care of 13 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizers and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, James had a good maize yield harvesting 15 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, James was only able to harvest five bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to James and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, James will educate his children and will use the rest of the cash domestically.

In 2012, the members of Khako SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, James is pictured with his group members. The Field Officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Mwanzo B Group

texts.en:
Everlyne is the facilitator of the Mwanzo B group. Her group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Everlyne is a mother of four children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate her children. In the recent 2011 season, Everlyne had a good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Everlyne was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Everlyne and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Everlyne will build a house and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Mwanzo B group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
Everlyne is pictured with her group members, with their Field Officer, Ben, on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Dahir Abdi

texts.en:
Dahir still runs his restuarant which is doing well. He is married to Halimah who also assists him in managing the restuarant. He earns an income of 8,000 KES. This is the fifth year the business has been in operation.

He is applying for his second loan term with KADET after repaying the previous loan successfully. Dahil will use the loan amount to buy maize meal, sugar and cooking oil for his restuarant. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, he will provide for the basic needs of his family. His hopes and dreams are to open a restaurant which will provide for the needs of his future family.

loans.use: to buy flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Bambu Kuning Group

texts.en:
Nurmah is married with three children.  She is pictured in the photo wearing the white headscarf.  She has been selling "pecel" (vegetables in peanut sauce), fried snacks, and cakes for the last fifteen years around her neighborhood.  So far it's been going well and the income can meet the needs of the home. Her husband is self-employed.  Two of their children are in high school.  School is important for the children because she herself only attended through elementary school.  

As there are no competitors in her neighborhood, she hopes the business can always go smoothly and the profits grow. This is her second loan with VisionFund Indonesia and she will use it to buy more ingredients to grow the business. She wants her family to always have enough income for their day to day living expenses.

The other group members have businesses which include selling lunch boxes of rice, chicken, etc., swimming pool maintenance, making handicrafts, and selling mobile phone minutes.

loans.use: to pay for ingredients to make and sell "pecel" (vegetables in peanut sauce), fried snacks, and cakes.

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is aged 34 and married with five children. The first four are already in school. She has been in farming for the last four years and currently employs one farmhand who helps her produce milk, maize, beans and vegetables in her home area of Kitale, Western Kenya. She is also in a motorcycle transport business.

Frida has requested for a loan of 100,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to enable her to construct a greenhouse where she will grow tomatoes for commercial purposes. She adds the greenhouse will make her production possible in all seasons and benefit her especially during the dry season when the supply is poor in the market.

She is grateful for Juhudi Kilimo's support and reiterates that the loans will economically empower smallholder farmers.

loans.use: To construct a greenhouse

loans.name: Makunda B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Makunda B Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
